Nice and balanced, a very well done sour with a huge taste in a smaller ABV.

On tap at Capone¬ís and beautiful. Pours brown with ruby highlights.  Aroma of cherries, raspberries, and vinegar.  Tart cherry and raspberry flavor with yeast flavor intertwined.  Sour ending.  Impressive.

Serving: Draft.
Appearance: Ruddy brown color with small, off-white head.  Lesser head retention.
Aroma: Sour cherries, some oak notes, a strong whiff of vinegar.  Clean and nice.
Flavor: Lots of fruit notes with cherries and raspberries chiming in.  Nice tart note and a slight bit of funkiness.  Very refreshing.
Mouthfeel: Highly carbonated, light on the tongue and it finishes surprisingly clean.
Overall: One of the best sours I¬íve had.  I could have a couple of these.

Reddish brown color with a small, off white head that left nice lacing on the glass.  Aroma of wood, some vanilla, vinegar, cherries, and wild yeast.  Taste of cherries, wood, nuts, some acidity, and a tart finish.

Tap @ Toronado S.D.  Pours a deep reddish brown with a small off white ring.  Nice nose of tart cherry, oak tannin and a touch of vinegar.  Flavor starts tart with cherry and other berry fruits, then gives way to dry oak and some wine tannin.  Awesome stuff.

Pours a reddish brown with a thin egg shell halo. 
Nose is tart with cherries, oak, and hints of vinegar. 
Taste is fairly sour, slightly puckering up front, cherry, cranberry, nice woody middle, hints of oak, finishes with a touch of vinegar heat. Great beer that is sure to cause ring sting.

On tap at Churchkey into tumbler. Pours a deep red with almost no head. No lacing. Aroma is very intense Flemish sour: big sour cherries, port wine soaked oak, some lactose, light balsamic vinegar. Taste is similar: sour cherries, raw raspberries, and wild yeast give this an insane sour body that is addictive to the palate. You just want more and more of this! Super drinkable. Just awesome.

On Tap at Toronado San Diego. Deep red color; minimal head. Well-soured acidic aroma. Quite sour flavor, medium carbonation; tastes great. This is the kind of Flanders Red that I prefer, more sour cherries and less balsamic vinegar. I don¬ít know if this is the same beer as the Ommegang Rouge, but I can¬ít tell any difference and they are both stand out Flemish sours.

On tap at Capone¬ís.  Pours a nice red color.  Smell is sour with cherries, like sour cherries!  Mouthfeel is nice and light.  Taste is sour up front with cherries on the back side.  Sourness is not overpowering and blends nice with the sweetness of the cherries.  An excellent sour.  I tried this along with the Ommegang Rouge, also brewed by Bockor.  They were indeed very similar with one being slightly more cherry taste than the other (can¬ít remember which).  But only slightly so and that was probably due to the difference in the age of the beers.

Draft at Belgian Beer Weekend in Brussels. Darker;, light hazt blond coloured beer with a small white head and almost no carbonation. Sour fruity balanced aroma, hints of grains and sour appel. Medium sprankling palate with a refreshing taste. Finish is light sour and dry ending with some fruity sour, light grainy and cereal dry hints.

Tap at Capones.  Pours a lightly hazy deep copper with a medium creamy off white lacing head.  Aroma of tart cherry, green apple and bready notes.  Flavor of the same.  Great sourness meets tart cherry.  Very smooth.

On tap at Capone¬ís. Poured a medium brownish (with a red tint) color with an averaged sized head. Aromas of cherries, vinegar, and some funkiness. Tastes of cherries, the same lighter funkiness, and lighter vinegar (which was stronger in the aromas). Lighter tartness.

UPDATED: DEC 22, 2009 Draught at Capone¬ís:  Aroma of light tart fruit, cherries, and light funk.  Poured deep amber/copper/cola in color with a medium to large-sized creamy, dense, beige/light brown head that lasted throughout.  The head was beautiful.  Clear.  Slightly sparkling.  Excellent lacing.  Flavor is light to medium tart and lightly sweet.  Tastes of tart cherries, barnyard, and funk.  Medium body.  Slick, slightly dry texture.  Soft to average carbonation.  Lightly tart, cherry and funk finish is slightly dry.

UPDATED: JUN 29, 2011 2010-06-02, RBESG 2010, draught at Brasserie 4:20, 7-3-7-3-15=35Light blond color. Strong acidic and acetic aroma, with a dash of Bretts. Lean body, with low carbonation; a feeling of uva fragola; sour; citric. Refreshing.2009-10-17, draught at Spuyten Duyvil, New York, 8-5-7-3-15=38Red mahogany color. Nice aroma, lactic, with caramel and cellar smell. Reasonable body structure; caramel flavor, light residual sweetness, interesting fruit profile (cherries, but also raspberries, and some cherry kernels); medium lactic sourness. The final is lightly astringent and woody, a bit sour, but also short. Pleasant, it reminds me the Rodenbach family. Good.

Served on tap at Toronados. The appearance is a grainy red with some brown notes. The flavors and aromas are a nice sour cherry with some oak tones. The mouth is nicely carbonated to carry the sour tart. A great recommendation by the bartender.

Live rate, on tap at the Maproom.  Glad this was on long enough for me to get down here to try it.  Dark clear red with an creamy beige pink head.  Sour and earthy funk aromas of raspberries, hay, earthiness, with residual sugars.  Tart raspberries and red fruit flavors pucker my lips on first sip, but with the sweetness it¬ís not too strong.  Lightly sweet, red fruits, with some vinegar acidity in the back of the mouth.  Body is on the thin side, but this is hardly noticeable with the tart fruit flavors.  A solid birthday beer, just what I¬ím in the mood for.
Aroma of sour apple, raspberries and red grape. Appearance was deep red with creamy head. Flavors of red grape, raspberries and sour apple. Palate was bubbly, mouthfeel was large. Delicious!

On Tap @ Maproom, Pours a really deep slightly muddy ruby color with a fingers worth of tan head. Aroma is sour cherries, wood some light malt undertones. Flavor is balsamic and red wine vinegar with cherries, dark fruit, a little woodiness. Really nice and sour/tart through the back end. Interesting brew from Cantillon.

Draft at The Map Room.  Pour is clear dark red with a bit of tan head.  Strong nose of tart cherries, and some earthy malt character.  Same in the flavor.  Quite complexe.  Certainly more going on here that a lot of the other sour bombs that I¬íve come across.

Draft @ Falling ROck. Pretty dark red with mimimal head. Lots of sour apple and cider vinegar in the nose - taste is the same as the nose, with a little wood at first. FInish is puckering with too much vinegar/vegetable sourness for my liking. OK - not something I¬íd go back for.

On tap at Toronado San Diego.  Deep dark reddish amber color with a small off white head fading to a ring.  Sour apple, vinegar, and cherry on the aroma.  Flavor is green apple, red wine, vinegar, oak, and sour cherry.  Really tasty, not too tart with a mild sweetness to it.  Palate is smooth with mild acidity and lively carbonation.  Body is medium-light.

UPDATED: MAR 18, 2010 (Draught and Growler)  Pours a hazy red body with a small off-white head.  Aroma of subtle cherries, earth, leather, fresh florals, light vanilla, plum, and wood.  Flavor of earth, sweet cherries, wood, funky, and some vinegar.

Pouring at the Night of the Funk event in Boston.  Pours a just hazy brown with a medium tanned beige head.  Light stone fruit, wood, funk.  Little bit sweet, and a lot like Ommegang Rouge, but a bit sweeter and not as much vinegar and acid to it.  Still tasty though.

Tap at Night of the Funk. Vegetal, sour, kimchi aroma. Spritzy with medium levels of acidity. Salad greens and sugary wort. I drank this at the very end of the night, so I¬íll need to revisit it, but at least the initial impression showed this to be no Ommegang Rouge.

On tap at Falling Rock poured a clear dark reddish amber with a lingering ring of amber foam. Aromas of sour cherry, basalmic vinegar, toffee, light barnyard and a hint of spice. Palate was light bodied and crisp with a tart finish. Flavors of sour cherry, oak, barnyard and light basalmic vinegar with a crisp lingering tart finish.

Tap at the maproom- Chicago.  Brown pour with garnet hues.  Fluffy tan head and spotty lace.  Figs, sour cherry and vinegar on the nose.  Full acidic mouth-feel with notable hints of cherry, lemon and light vinegar.  Really solid flanders

(draft) Clear deep red body with a touch of brown, topped by a small beige head.  Aroma is medium sweet, wood, sour cherry.  Taste is medium sweet, wood, cherry, good sourness, fair sweetness to complement the sourness.  Light-medium body, light stickiness, acidity.  A wonderful Flemish sour -- a bit bolder than the Duchesse.

Draft @ The Trappist. Pretty much just stumbled upon this one (Ali was the one who actually ordered it, after I¬íd ordered a pour of Allagash Confluence.) Pours a deep, clear ruby-red color; off-white head with glistening, fine-bubbled lacing; good retention. Generous aroma of tart red fruits: well-soured, highly acidic, cherry pits and lemon, with a light core. Medium-to-full mouthfeel: very nicely sour, mouthwatering: tart citrus, red fruits, high acidity; just a touch of oak in the background, if at all; a very solid, rather straightforward and intense sour red ale. Sweet tart red fruit. Lasting finish of sour red fruits, citrus; tartness lasts.

Draft op tap at the Binnys South Loop taproom (Chicago, IL). Pours a deep dark brown with glowing rusty red, dark and not quite opaque, a moderate brownish tan head that stays at a decent film, laces well. Aromas are a good potent sour cherries feel, a touch sweeter, with a good sourness, light vinegar, and wet wood with a bit of funkiness in there. Nice sourness, moderate. Initial is a decent body, decent sourness with a touch of vinegar, dry and lightly vanilla oak come into play, some lactic sourness sticks to the palate, decent sourness, decent acidity, with a touch of vinegar, sour cherries that push a little more sweetness that temper the sourness a little more and kinda mute the finish and aftertaste just a bit. A solid sour, more sessionable but lacking a ton of complexity. Still, quite tasty and very welcome after a long work weekend. Cheers all.

This is a surprise, its rare to be able to gte a new sour these days without trying.  Tap @ Small Bar in SD.  Pours orange with a tan head.  Big tart nose, taste is decently tart too.  Surprisingly deent.

On tap at The Belgian Cafe in the Fairmount section of Philadelphia.  Very deep maroon color, little head, and with a deliciously tart and nicely sour cherry flavor.  Right up there with the best of the Flemish sours.

12oz pour at Pizza Paradiso in Dupont Circle, Washington D.C.  Pours a slightly translucent purple, mahogany amber with a very very thin, ringing white head.  The aroma is my only complaint about this beer.  At first the nose has very little, as it warms some tart berry aromas come out, cherry and cranberry mostly, red grapes, a little funk, a little hay, a little bit of citrus fruit.  Flavor is spot on for a sour: bitter from citrus fruits, tart from the acid, strong lactic acid flavor, sweet ripe fruits, slight funk, toasted grain, a little splash of wood.  Finish is tart, bitter, sweet and dry.  I liked Ommegang Rouge better based mostly on the aroma but the flavors were also more developed.  This was very drinkable though, something you could drink many of.

UPDATED: SEP 13, 2009 Tap at small bar. Pours a ruby red with a beige head.  Notes of sour cherries, horse blank funk. Flavor is. Medium tartness,chocolate, funk.  Like a fua funkier version of la folie? But I¬ím drunk and typing this on my fucked up phone. Awesome beer though. Great balance. Nice funky tartness. don¬ít pass up the chance to try this
On tap at The Trappist. This black beer poured with a generous beige head and a wild fruity aroma. There is an excellent sour brown flavor with a little bit of cherry and a strong dry finish.

Tap at Ginger Man. After hearing of the connection between this and Ommegang Rouge, I assumed this was a different batch of the same beer, but apparently I was mistaken. The profile is remarkably similar. Pours brownish red. Subtle tart fruit aroma I wish were more intense. Lots or cranberry, cherry, and strawberry flavors with a strong funky bite. In comparison to Ommegang Rouge, this has slightly more bite and a dryer finish. All in all, it¬ís a slightly different angle of the same wonderful beast.

On tap at the Maproom, Chicago, IL.  Hazy, ruby red with small white/pinkish head.  Aroma is sour cherry, oak, dryer, grapey, acidic.  Flavor is sour cherry, light grapiness, a little acidity, light oak, a little cola, sweeter.  Medium to light body with light carbonation.  Love the aroma, very similar to rodenbach grand cru but the flavor is a little too much cola.

Tap at Lucky Baldwin¬ís.  This is great indeed.  Aroma is subtle with red malts, sweet berry.  Flavor kicks you right in the face with an extreme rounded fruity sour that changes the expression on your face.  Really crisp, and the only Flemish sour I like.

On Tap at Pizzaria Paradisio.  Pours a really deep slightly muddy ruby color with a fingers worth of tan head.  Aroma is sour cherries, wood some light malt undertones.  Flavor is balsamic and red wine vinegar with cherries, dark fruit, a little woodiness.  Really nice and sour/tart through the back end.  Great beer.

Draft at Pizzaria Paradiso.  Wow! Pours a very dark garnet.  Aroma is sour fruit, vinegar and some malt.  Flavor is mostly sour apple and red wine vinegar, with a decent malt background.  The sour kick grows through the finish with a tart aftertaste.  Fantastic!  Exactly what I want from a Flemish Red.
Draft at Ebenezer¬ís.  Reddish brown with ring and lace.  Cherry woody sweet aroma.  Woody cherry tart sour charry with dry tart finish.  Sweet dry and soft.  Excellent.

Tap at south loop binny¬ís... Pours a darker garnet red with a velvety light beige head... Light red fruit, tartness, and vinegar... Flavors are much of the same. Tart red fruit, not too dry, a litle vinous. Semi-lively carbonation but an all around tasty brew.  Sweeter through the middle and finishes tart.

On draft at the new Pizzeria Paradiso in Dupont Circle.  Reddish brown color with scant off white head.  Aroma of dark fruit and malt.  Medium body, sour cherry taste with a background of very slight smoke.  No hops to speak of.  Nice example of a Flemish style, reminiscent of the old Rodenbach Grand Cru.

An expressive sour ale.  Warm raisin-like aroma and a dark brown color made me think it was going to be sweeter than it turned out.  A strong sour grape/cherry acidic flavor with a dry bitter finish.  A full glass was almost too much for me, but that is simply because that is not a style I¬ím all about.  On tap at Lucky Baldwin¬ís Belgian Fest.

On draft at Devil¬ís DenRuby body, small pink head. Nose is heavy cherry, some musty brett, and light alcohol. Flavor is more cherry, heavy pit, also rather tart and with light vinegar. Not as flemish as expected, way fruitier. Fantastic carbonation, very juicy. Incredibly drinkable and tasty.

On tap @ Beachwood BBQ.  Clear copper orange with a creamy beige head, good retention.  Flavor has bright cherry pulp and vanilla with some lactic sourness and bretty funk behind.  Kinda reminds me of Duchesse du Bourgogne, but better because it isn¬ít sickeningly sweet.  Dry woody and cherry skin finish with sourness around a 4, with a little wheat as well.  Backing up, the aroma was much the same, only less sweet. Moderate creamy carbonation with a medium body.  Pretty tasty.
user_location: Ocean Beach, San Diego, California, USA

text:
I had this on tap at Beachwood¬ís Sour Fest.

This pours a clear dark red and has a very nice fruity (?cherry, ?plum) flavor that is balanced with some tangy tartness.

Draft at Ebenezer¬ís. Pours a red-brown with a nice fluff head. Nose strongly acidic, no funk. Light lemon and cherry notes. Taste is much the same, with a light sweetness and more of the cherry notes. Strong acidity that really shows you what a good Flanders Red is. Excellent Excellent stuff.

On tap at Beachwood for Sour Fest.  So, there are obvious similarities to Ommegang Rouge here (which was ALSO on tap!), being as they are both made by Bocker.  First, may I just say that that is not a bad thing.  Compared to the latter, this beer pours a bit darker (a dark amber-brown), and has, I think, a bit ¬ìdarker¬î of a flavor.  Aroma is tart cherries, toasted malt, oak and firm acidity.  Flavor starts with cherries and smooth vanilla.  There is also some defined green apple and oak flavor that renders the flavor profile more complex.  This is not unlike how I describe Ommegang Rouge, though.  Palate had prickly carbonation, with actually stunted the flavors for a split-moment, then allowed them to come streaming out as it subsided.  A delicious beer, though I would be interested to know from Bocker how it differs from Ommegang¬ís

On tap.  The pour is a nice clear reddish brown with a fairly small white head.  Aroma is cherry, raspberry, oak, sour funk, and very very clean.  Smells wonderful.  Flavor is huge tart cherry and raspberry up front with a pleasantly mild oakiness and faint sweetness.  This beer is quite tart but with a crisp finish that makes me want to have more and more.  I really like this.

Tap at Binny¬ís (South Loop location): Rusty copper brownish pour with a ruby hue and a well retained light tan head. Nice acetic aroma with an oaky vinousness, tart raspberry fruitiness. Creamy body with a sharp acidity. Vinegary tartness with fruity notes of passionfruit and raspberry. There¬ís a light vanilla-ish note of tannic oak. The soft sweetness is dried out nicely by the acetic and oak presence. Very nice. Similar to the Ommegang Rouge.

On tap at Hopleaf in early July of 2009. pours clear ruby with off white head. nose is loaded with vinegar, acidic sour cherries, and funky wild yeast. flavors are rather acidic tart cherries with a nice balance of sweet malts. very nice!

On tap at the Maproom.  Pours a very dark wine red, clear, but too dark to see thru, small egg-shell color fizzy froth 3.5.  Super strong vinegar aroma, balsamic and acidic, nostril coatingly thick, barnyard funk, grainy, musty 8.5.  First taste is rough and unrefined, super acidic and extra sweet, similar to the Haandbakk, extremely sweet and sour, after the palate adjust it becomes unbelievably grapy, tart cranberries and bitter fruit skins, aggressive 8.5.  Medium bodied with a thin diet-soda-like airy carbonation feel 4.
